title: RL31919
content: According to the Federal Trade Commission, identity theft is the most common complaint from consumers in all 50 states, accounting for over 35% of total complaints received for calendar years 2004-2006. In 2006, out of 674,354 complaints, 36% were related to identity theft. Victims may experience credit card fraud, phone/utilities fraud, bank fraud, employment-related fraud, government documents/benefits fraud, loan fraud, and other types of fraud. This can result in damaged credit records, unauthorized charges, unauthorized withdrawals, and the need to change personal information like phone numbers and social security numbers. The report provides an overview of federal laws assisting victims of identity theft in removing inaccurate information from credit records and prosecuting impostors using fraudulent identification documents. The Identity Theft Assumption Deterrence Act prohibits fraud related to identification documents, including offenses directly linked to consumer identity theft. This Act makes it a federal crime to produce or possess false identification documents under certain circumstances. It is a federal crime to possess or use stolen or unlawfully produced identification documents of the United States. Punishments vary depending on the offense, with fines or imprisonment up to 15 years for certain violations. Offenses related to fraud with identification documents can result in imprisonment for up to three years, with harsher penalties for crimes involving drug trafficking or violence. The Identity Theft Penalty Enhancement Act, signed in 2004, defines penalties for aggravated identity theft. Offenses committed in connection with terrorism can result in additional imprisonment. Aggravated identity theft occurs when a person unlawfully uses another person's identification during certain felonies, leading to a two-year imprisonment in addition to the original felony punishment. Terrorism-related offenses can add five years to the sentence. The Identity Theft Penalty Enhancement Act of 2004 defines penalties for aggravated identity theft, including additional imprisonment for offenses connected to terrorism. The act also authorized appropriations for the investigation and prosecution of identity theft cases. The Fair Credit Reporting Act offers assistance to victims by allowing them to have negative information removed from their credit files. The Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) outlines consumer rights regarding credit reports, permissible uses, and accuracy requirements. Consumers can sue for violations, such as inaccurate information or identity theft issues. The FCRA allows lawsuits within two years of discovering a violation or five years of the violation occurring. The FACT Act of 2003 amended the FCRA to include various changes. The FACT Act of 2003 amended the Fair Credit Reporting Act to prevent identity theft and assist victims. New provisions require credit card issuers to follow procedures for address changes and truncation of account numbers on receipts. Consumers can request fraud alerts and have social security numbers truncated on credit reports. Fraud alerts can be placed on a consumer's credit file for 90 days, with the option to extend it for up to seven years. This alert is shared with all users of the credit report and must be included in any credit score generated. Victims of identity theft can also request to have fraudulent information blocked from their credit reports by providing proof of identity theft. The consumer reporting agency must block the information and notify the furnisher of the data. Requests for blocking information due to identity theft must be referred to other consumer reporting agencies. Victims of identity theft can request information about the crime and receive copies of application and transaction records from businesses upon verification of their identity. The Fair Credit Billing Act allows consumers to dispute unauthorized charges and resolve billing errors in credit transactions. The Fair Credit Billing Act (FCBA) allows consumers to dispute unauthorized charges and resolve billing errors. Consumers can file a claim with the creditor to have errors resolved, and until then, they are not required to pay the disputed amount. The Electronic Fund Transfer Act (EFTA) provides a mechanism for challenging unauthorized transactions and having accounts recredited in case of errors. The Electronic Fund Transfer Act (EFTA) establishes rights and liabilities for electronic fund transfer systems. It limits a consumer's liability for unauthorized transfers to $50 if reported within two business days. Financial institutions must provide documentation of transfers and investigate any errors reported by consumers within 60 days. The consumer must notify the financial institution of any errors in documentation within 10 business days. If an error is confirmed, the institution must correct it within one day and may temporarily credit the consumer's account. The President's Identity Theft Task Force recommended a plan to combat identity theft in April 2007. The President's Identity Theft Task Force recommended a plan to combat identity theft in April 2007, focusing on protecting personal information, assisting law enforcement in prosecuting identity thieves, educating consumers and businesses, and increasing data security measures. Recommendations include amending statutes to prosecute identity thieves who target corporations, adding new crimes to the list of offenses for aggravated identity theft, and enhancing prosecution and punishment to deter identity theft. The Department of Homeland Security published the final rule for State-issued driver's licenses and identification cards in accordance with the REAL ID Act of 2005, establishing standards for minimum requirements. This includes incorporating information and security features, verifying identity and legal status, and ensuring document security. The final rule for State-issued driver's licenses and identification cards under the REAL ID Act of 2005 sets standards for verifying applicant information and document security. States have until December 31, 2009, to comply, with possible extensions for meeting security benchmarks. The enrollment period is extended to December 1, 2014, for those born after December 1, 1964, and December 1, 2017, for those born on or before that date, with the rule effective from March 31, 2008.
